articles.headline: Lush Land Dries Up, Withering Kenya’s Hopes
articles.snippet: A devastating drought is sweeping across Kenya, imperiling agriculture and tourism as well as spawning ethnic conflict.
articles.abstract: A devastating drought is sweeping across Kenya, imperiling agriculture and tourism as well as spawning ethnic conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOKORI, Kenya  The sun somehow feels closer here, more intense, more personal. As Philip Lolua waits under a tree for a scoop of food, heat waves dance up from the desert floor, blurring the dead animal carcasses sprawled in front of him.

articles.headline: Crux of Afghan Debate: Will More Troops Curb Terror?
articles.snippet: Some counterterrorism experts say alternatives to a troop buildup include drone strikes, commando raids and enlisting Afghan warlords in the fight against Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: Some counterterrorism experts say alternatives to a troop buildup include drone strikes, commando raids and enlisting Afghan warlords in the fight against Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Does the United States need a large and growing ground force in Afghanistan to prevent another major terrorist attack on American soil?
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Seeking the World’s Biggest Meatball? Try Mexico.
articles.snippet: It has been a good year for world records in Mexico, from the world’s largest cheesecake to the biggest smooch fest.
articles.abstract: It has been a good year for world records in Mexico, from the world’s largest cheesecake to the biggest smooch fest.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  If Guinness World Records ever creates a category for the country most obsessed with being in the Guinness book of world records, Mexico will surely be in the running.

articles.headline: Closely Watched Buffett Recalculating His Bets
articles.snippet: After investing billions during the financial crisis, Warren Buffett’s company is now buying fewer stocks.
articles.abstract: After investing billions during the financial crisis, Warren Buffett’s company is now buying fewer stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett has two cardinal rules of investing. Rule No. 1: Never lose money. Rule No. 2: Never forget Rule No. 1.

articles.headline: Removal of Leader Stirs Anger Over Dealings of Actuary Group
articles.snippet: When the American Academy of Actuaries removed its leader, it set off a storm of criticism and legal wrangling.
articles.abstract: When the American Academy of Actuaries removed its leader, it set off a storm of criticism and legal wrangling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Actuaries, the public face of a behind-the-scenes profession, is in disarray after quietly sacking its incoming president, then trying to conceal both his ouster and an unpleasant secret from his past.

articles.headline: Google Tackles Fears on Rights in Book Deal
articles.snippet: Many authors, artists and publishers fear Google’s proposal to digitize works that are out of print but still have copyright protection.
articles.abstract: Many authors, artists and publishers fear Google’s proposal to digitize works that are out of print but still have copyright protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  Google said it would limit the out-of-print books it plans to make available online in order to appease European publishers, authors and other copyright holders objecting to a proposed American court settlement allowing Google to sell digital books on the Internet.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Eric Pfanner

articles.headline: A Breakdown on Handling Big Failures
articles.snippet: The United States appears to be in no better position today to manage the failure of a large financial institution than it was a year ago.
articles.abstract: The United States appears to be in no better position today to manage the failure of a large financial institution than it was a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Henry M. Paulson Jr., then the Treasury secretary, gave a little noticed speech in London in July 2008.

articles.headline: Signs of an Upswing in Merger Activity
articles.snippet: Kraft Foods’ hostile bid for Cadbury was only the latest potential blockbuster deal in recent days. But activity is much lower than the last few years.
articles.abstract: Kraft Foods’ hostile bid for Cadbury was only the latest potential blockbuster deal in recent days. But activity is much lower than the last few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merger mania may not be quite in full swing. But the pace of deal-making is showing signs of rousing back to life after nearly a year.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
